surgical_rate.evidence: Nationwide study of 53,688 ruptures showing sustained increased incidence with surgical decline

key_finding: Achilles tendon rupture incidence has increased by 45% while surgical interventions have decreased by 55%

surgical_rate.evidence: National registry data showing decreasing surgical interventions from 16.9 to 6.3 per 100,000

key_finding: Decreasing trend in surgical management, with significant shift toward non-operative treatment

surgical_rate.evidence: Decrease in operative treatment from 13.6 to 4.9 per 100,000 person-years between 1997 and 2019

incidence.trend: Increase from 17.3 to 32.3 per 100,000 person-years between 1997 and 2019

demographics.affected_groups: Increase in all age groups, most markedly among the elderly

key_finding: ATR incidence increased while operative treatment decreased significantly. The plateau in incidence during the second half of the study period suggests stabilization.

surgical_rate.evidence: Systematic review and meta-analysis of 10 RCTs and 19 observational studies

demographics.study_types: 10 randomised controlled trials (944 patients) and 19 observational studies (14,918 patients)

outcomes.re_rupture_risk: Lower with surgery (2.3% vs 3.9%, RR 0.43, 95% CI 0.31-0.60)
outcomes.complication_risk: Higher with surgery (4.9% vs 1.6%, RR 2.76, 95% CI 1.84-4.13)

key_finding: Operative treatment reduces re-rupture risk but increases complications. Final decision should be based on patient-specific factors and shared decision-making.

surgical_rate.trend: Slight decrease but remained predominantly surgical
surgical_rate.evidence: Analysis of national health insurance database

key_finding: Incidence of Achilles tendon ruptures has increased with continued preference for surgical management

surgical_rate.trend: Selective approach to treatment with 39.4% treated surgically
surgical_rate.evidence: Consecutive series of 363 patients over 8.5 years (143 operative, 220 nonoperative)

incidence.trend: High incidence, particularly among women due to netball injuries

demographics.gender_distribution: Equal male:female ratio up to age 50, 73% male in 51-60 age group
demographics.common_cause: Netball was the most common cause of injury, explaining high female incidence

outcomes.nonsurgical_rerupture: 8.6% re-rupture rate in non-operative group (11.5% males, 5.6% females)
outcomes.age_factor: Lower re-rupture rate in patients over 40 (4.1%) vs under 40 (13.1%) in non-operative group

key_finding: Results support surgery in patients under 40 years (particularly males) if no contraindications. Functional bracing with non-operative treatment yields low re-rupture rates in patients over 40, especially females.

surgical_rate.evidence: Coincided with publication of high-quality RCTs showing similar outcomes between 'functional' non-operative management and surgical repair

key_finding: Surgical repair rates have substantially decreased while Achilles rupture incidence has increased

surgical_rate.evidence: Multicenter study of 405 patients across 21 sites in France with 24-month follow-up

outcomes.re_rupture_risk: No significant difference (4% surgical vs 9% non-surgical, p=0.176)
outcomes.functional_scores: Better in surgical group (ATRS p=0.017, EFAS p=0.013, SF-12 physical p=0.01)
outcomes.complications: More general complications in conservative group (24% vs 11%, p=0.04)
outcomes.surgery_specific: 9% rate of surgery-related complications (infection, nerve damage)

key_finding: Strong preference for surgical treatment despite similar re-rupture rates. Early weightbearing and mobilization within 30 days optimized outcomes without increasing re-rupture risk.

surgical_rate.evidence: Nationwide registry study of 118,652 cases from 2001-2015

demographics.gender: Higher prevalence in men of working age

outcomes.projection: 2.65% growth in surgical procedures predicted by 2025

key_finding: Surgical management remains the standard of care across all regions of Italy, with the highest rate of procedures in the northern regions

surgical_rate.trend: Slight decline but still predominantly surgical

key_finding: Operation remains standard therapy, though trend toward conservative functional therapy exists

surgical_rate.trend: Increase in surgical treatment from 67% in 2010 to 72% in 2017
surgical_rate.evidence: Analysis of national health insurance database

key_finding: Japan shows a counter-trend with increasing surgical treatment rates compared to Western countries

surgical_rate.trend: Surgical repair rate remained stable at around 70%
surgical_rate.evidence: Analysis of Medicare database with 14,127 Achilles tendon ruptures

demographics.gender_distribution: No significant difference between males (6,636) and females (7,582)
demographics.age_factor: Older patients, especially those >85 years, more likely to be treated nonoperatively

outcomes.regional_variation: No differences in treatment patterns based on region

key_finding: The incidence of Achilles tendon ruptures is increasing with time, but the trend in operative and nonoperative treatment remained stable between 2005 and 2015. Treatment decisions appear to be influenced primarily by patient age.

surgical_rate.trend: 68% decrease in surgical repairs between 2009 and 2014, continuing to decline to 12.3% by 2019
surgical_rate.evidence: Analysis of Victorian Orthopaedic Trauma Outcomes Registry and subsequent national studies

demographics.bimodal_distribution: First peak at 25-40 years (sports injuries), second peak >60 years (low-energy injuries)

outcomes.non_operative_success: Supervised non-operative management with functional rehabilitation protocols shows comparable outcomes to surgery
outcomes.complication_rates: 30% complication rate with surgery vs 8% with non-operative treatment

key_finding: Australia shows a significant shift away from surgical management, with a 68% decrease in surgical repairs from 2009-2014, mirroring international trends. This shift is attributed to emerging high-quality evidence supporting non-surgical approaches with lower complication rates.

surgical_rate.evidence: Prospective ED cohort showing only 2.9% underwent surgery

incidence.trend: Stable at ~8 per 100,000 person-years over 5 years

key_finding: Emergency-department surveillance in central England found an incidence of 8/100k with overwhelming preference for non-operative management and two-thirds of injuries sport-related.

surgical_rate.note: Treatment modality distribution not specified in incidence paper

incidence.trend: Gradual rise until 2008 followed by decline

key_finding: First Central-European regional study shows moderate incidence with very high male predominance and sports as leading cause; bilateral ruptures extremely rare (0.1/100k).

surgical_rate.trend: Proportion surgically treated declined from 43% to 25%

demographics.highest_risk: Men aged 40+ participating in high-demand sports

key_finding: Nationwide registry confirms rising incidence but rapidly falling operative rates in Sweden during 2001-2012, preceding the larger 2002-2021 dataset.
